entry.title: What is eCATT error TT377 Control data is obsolete, rerecord (&1&2&3) ?
entry.content:
I'm running an eCATT on an S/4HANA system (ABAP 7.58 SP 1) and I get the below error TT377:

Control data is obsolete, rerecord (VERBS-NAME: GETGUISERVICES CATT: GETDATAASFORMAT Callno: 000010)

The eCATT was created on an old ABAP system (ECC 6.0, ABAP 7.31) and it contains only one TCD command (Batch Input).

I see there are other same questions but with different VERBS-NAME (e.g. CREATEOBJECT), CATT (e.g. GETGUISERVICES, CREATE, <none>, SHOWDATA) or Callno, the answers were unclear what it means and what to do.

What means this message and how to solve it?

Thanks.

Sandra

entry.title: Re: What is eCATT error TT377 Control data is obsolete, rerecord (&1&2&3) ?
entry.content:
The error message TT377 "Control data is obsolete, rerecord (&1&2&3)" means that the list of called OCX control methods (called "verbs") is different from the list of called OCX control methods when the eCATT was recorded:

  • The placeholder &1 ("VERBS-NAME") is the OCX control method ("verb") currently called.
  • The placeholder &2 ("CATT") is the OCX control method which was recorded at the time the eCATT was recorded, and which is expected.

For information:

  • The error message TT377 is sent by the function module CAT_CONTROLS_PLAYBACK.
  • The list of the recorded OCX verbs is stored in the table ECSCR_TVER.

I have no idea if this discrepancy between expected and actual verbs is critical or not, but by default it makes the script fail.

Solution

In my case, if I wrap the TCD command between the commands MESSAGE (MODE = 'A',  EXIT = <empty value>, MSGTYP = 'A', MSGID = 'TT', MSGNR = 377) and ENDMESSAGE (empty interface).

  • MODE = 'A' means "Allowed", i.e. if the message happens, there's no error, the next command inside the block MESSAGE/ENDMESSAGE is run, or if there's none the command after the block. For information, the standard behavior for the "A" (abort) error messages is MODE = 'F' (Failure),  EXIT = 'X' (execution skips to the ENDMESSAGE command).

If you don't want to use the block MESSAGE/ENDMESSAGE, you may rerecord the TCD command in the current system with exactly the same screens, and put back the original TCD command interface (for instance, type the variables manually).

For more information

About eCATT, see here: eCATT: extended Computer Aided Test Tool (BC-TWB-TST-ECA) | SAP Help Portal.

You may also refer to the list of all eCATT commands here: eCATT Command Reference | SAP Help Portal

NB: I'd be thankful to anyone who can explain the rationale of comparing the expected (when the TCD was recorded) and actual (when the TCD runs) lists of OCX control verbs.

entry.title: Re: eDocument Cockpit Incoming Supllier Invoice Colombia...
entry.content:
Analyzing the screens, the errors shown corresponds to the customer invoice not to the subsequent document (Acknowledge of invoice) sent to DIAN to verification.

The application when press "Check" creates the subsequent documents of acknowledge of invoice and receipt of goods, the information to create these new documents is extracted from the customer invoice that was uploaded, part of this information is the CUFE of the invoice.

 DIAN with the CUFE verify if the invoice was approved, if not return the rejection codes, this seems the case you report.

To verify if the invoice is approved and exists in DIAN site use the following links:

DIAN productive

DIAN Test

As final comments, taking in account this error codes do not belong to the process of incoming invoices, it seems to belong to the customer invoice process, our suggestion is to verify if the invoice is approved by DIAN and run again the incoming invoice process with an approved invoice, nevertheless you can post a case to SAP reporting any error.

Best Regards

Miguel Benitez

SAP Globalization Services

entry.title: Secure SAP–AI Integration Using Advantco OpenPGP Services
entry.content:
Secure SAP–AI Integration Using Advantco OpenPGP Services

1. Purpose and Scope

This article defines a secure, deployment-agnostic reference architecture for integrating SAP backend systems with external AI agents using OpenPGP-based cryptographic services provided by Advantco. The architecture separates cryptographic processing from data transport, ensuring that encryption, decryption, signing, and verification are performed by a dedicated cryptographic service layer, while message routing and orchestration remain the responsibility of the calling application or integration layer.

The architecture is intended for hybrid enterprise environments in which SAP backend systems may be deployed on-premise, in private cloud, on hyperscalers, or under RISE with SAP. AI agents may run on external platforms or managed AI services. Advantco OpenPGP services are exposed as APIs (REST and/or SOAP) and may be deployed on SAP Business Technology Platform or an equivalent enterprise runtime. This document describes a logical reference architecture and does not prescribe a specific deployment topology.

The scope of this document is limited to secure data exchange and trust establishment between SAP systems and AI agents. AI model behavior, prompt engineering, SAP business logic, and transport-level protocol selection are out of scope except where they affect security guarantees.

2. Architectural Rationale

Integrating SAP systems with external AI capabilities introduces a trust boundary between SAP-controlled environments and systems that operate outside SAP governance. This architecture addresses that boundary by enforcing message-level security that is independent of transport mechanisms and network topology.

Rather than embedding cryptographic logic into SAP applications or integration flows, the architecture externalizes OpenPGP operations into a dedicated cryptographic service layer. This allows encryption, decryption, signing, and verification to be centrally governed, audited, and evolved without requiring changes to SAP business applications. Transport and routing of messages remain the responsibility of SAP applications or integration components, preventing the cryptographic services from becoming an implicit integration broker.

3. Architectural Overview

The architecture consists of four logical concerns: SAP backend systems, an optional integration or orchestration layer, Advantco OpenPGP cryptographic services, and an external AI agent ecosystem.

SAP backend systems produce and consume business data but do not perform cryptographic operations directly. They rely on an integration or orchestration layer such as SAP Integration Suite, a SAP BTP application, or other middleware to coordinate message exchange with external systems where required.

Advantco OpenPGP services provide cryptographic transformation via APIs only. They do not perform message routing, transport, or forwarding.

External AI agents receive only signed and encrypted payloads and return responses in signed and encrypted form. Unencrypted payloads exist only within SAP-controlled trust boundaries.

Advantco OpenPGP provides cryptographic APIs only and returns results to the caller. Message transport and routing are handled by SAP or integration components and are not performed by Advantco.

4. Architecture Structure

From a business perspective, the architecture enables SAP processes to consume AI-generated insights without relinquishing control over data confidentiality or trust decisions. AI systems may influence SAP outcomes, but only after cryptographic validation and SAP-side authorization.

From an application perspective, the architecture separates responsibilities clearly. SAP backend systems focus on business logic. The integration or orchestration layer handles routing, retries, and protocol adaptation. Advantco OpenPGP services handle cryptographic transformation. AI agents handle AI processing only.

From an integration perspective, communication is message-based and transport-agnostic. Payload-level security is applied using OpenPGP before data crosses trust boundaries, ensuring that transport security is an additional layer rather than the primary protection mechanism.

From a data perspective, unencrypted payload exists only within SAP-controlled environments. Outside those boundaries, data is always exchanged in signed and encrypted form, accompanied by cryptographic metadata required for verification and audit.

5. Component Responsibilities

SAP backend systems remain the authoritative producers and consumers of business data. They initiate outbound requests and consume inbound results but delegate cryptographic processing to external services. SAP systems do not store or manage cryptographic private keys.

The integration or orchestration layer (where present) is responsible for transport, routing, protocol handling, retries, correlation, and error handling. It invokes Advantco OpenPGP APIs as required and forwards encrypted payloads to external AI agents, and returns verified payloads to SAP systems. It does not perform cryptographic operations beyond invoking the cryptographic service APIs.

Advantco OpenPGP services provide cryptographic operations as APIs. For outbound processing, they accept payloads and perform optional compression, message digest generation, digital signing, and OpenPGP hybrid encryption. For inbound processing, they accept encrypted payloads, verify digital signatures, decrypt content under governed key controls, and return verified payloads to the caller. These services are stateless with respect to message routing and do not forward data to external systems.

External AI agents operate outside the SAP trust boundary and are treated as untrusted by default. They can only process data that they have successfully decrypted and verified using trusted SAP public keys. AI agents sign and encrypt all outbound responses using their own private keys and do not receive access to SAP private keys or verified SAP payloads.

Key management is handled by a centralized Key Management Service that governs cryptographic key lifecycles, enforces usage policies, and records audit events. Agent identities are established by registering and allow-listing agent public keys, typically identified by fingerprints or key identifiers. Private keys remain protected and are never exposed outside the cryptographic service boundary.

6. Message Exchange

The Advantco OpenPGP APIs may be invoked directly by SAP applications or by an intermediate integration or orchestration layer. In all cases, Advantco performs cryptographic transformation only and does not forward messages.

In the outbound flow, SAP backend systems submit payloads for signing and encryption via the Advantco OpenPGP service. The service returns a signed and encrypted payload to the caller, which is responsible for forwarding the encrypted message to the external AI agent.

In the inbound flow, the external AI agent produces a signed and encrypted response. The encrypted response is submitted to the Advantco OpenPGP service for verification and decryption. The service returns a verified payload to the caller, which delivers the result to the SAP backend system.

The sequence diagram above illustrates the strict request–response nature of the Advantco OpenPGP APIs and the separation of cryptographic processing from message transport and routing.

7. Trust and Security Model

Trust in this architecture is based on cryptographic identity rather than network location. Public-key identities establish which parties may exchange data, while centralized key governance determines how keys may be used. By default, no shared secrets are required between SAP systems and AI agents.

Confidentiality is enforced through OpenPGP hybrid encryption. Integrity and authenticity are enforced through digital signatures. Auditability is provided through centralized logging of cryptographic operations. Replay protection is enforced by the receiving side using message identifiers, timestamps, and validity windows.

Cryptographic validity does not imply business authorization. AI-generated responses or instructions must still be validated against schemas, allow-listed actions, and SAP-side authorization rules before affecting SAP business processes.

8. Deployment Considerations

The architecture supports a wide range of deployment models, including scenarios in which SAP systems and integration components run on SAP BTP while cryptographic services are cloud-hosted and AI agents operate on external platforms. Security and correctness depend on logical separation of responsibilities rather than physical co-location.

As a concrete implementation option, Advantco OpenPGP services are available for deployment on SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP). In this model, the cryptographic services run as managed applications or services on SAP BTP and expose OpenPGP functionality through REST and/or SOAP APIs. SAP backend systems and SAP integration components can invoke these APIs directly using standard SAP-supported connectivity mechanisms. Deployment on SAP BTP does not change the logical architecture described in this document; Advantco OpenPGP continues to operate strictly as a cryptographic service and does not perform message routing or transport.

9. Conclusion

This reference architecture defines a clear separation between cryptographic services, message transport, and business logic for secure SAP–AI integration. By exposing OpenPGP operations as governed APIs and keeping data transport outside the cryptographic service boundary, the architecture enables strong security guarantees while remaining flexible, deployment-neutral, and suitable for enterprise use.

10. Sources

https://www.sap.com/products/technology-platform.html
https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc4880
https://owasp.org/www-project-api-security/
https://www.advantco.com/sap-integration-adapters/sap-pgp-integration

entry.title: Re: Update all worksheets & Guidelines - Compensation Module
entry.content:
Hi @magdalena_grabowicz 

1. Yes in my experience most organizations do not freeze data and run Update all worksheets job overnight during planning cycle (in Compensation, not VarPay). Customers can now schedule these jobs themselves since 2h 2025. The main drawback of "Update a specific worksheet" is that it doesn't allow people to move between worksheets based on planner change. Not even sure that it reflect eligibility the right way I'd need to test. The speed of all jobs has increased tremendously over the past release so for 11k employees I don't think it would take more than 20-30 minutes at this time.

2. It's rare to not have either of these two but it happens, for example for public sector organizations where increase % are negociated with unions, guideline based on the category of jobs you are in. Or in other cases predominantly based on only the payscale structure: Understanding SuccessFactors Pay Scale Structure and its related features

Best,

Xavier

entry.title: Define Account Determination for Treasury and Risk Management (TRM)
entry.content:
Purpose

This blog primarily introduces the configuration of Define Account Determination for Treasury and Risk Management (TRM).

If anything regarding TRM account determination has not been clarified in this blog post, please leave a comment and we will try to refine it as soon as possible.

Foundational Knowledge

To fully engage with the content ahead, familiarity with the following foundational concepts is mandatory:

  • Basic knowledge in general ledger accounting, account receivables, account payables, e.g., document types, posting keys, account types (e.g., D - Customers, K - Vendors, S - G/L accounts).
  • Valuation areas in TRM and how they are linked to accounting principles and ledgers.
    • Paying valuation area is linked to the leading ledger.
    • Nonpaying valuation areas are linked to the non-leading ledgers.
  • Update types in TRM and how they are determined from valuation area-independent operational cash flows, valuation area-dependent business transactions (e.g., valuation, accrual, derived business transactions), etc.
  • Account assignment references in TRM and how they are derived.
  • TRM position management and position change categories.
  • Bank account management in cash management.

Configuration activities

Configuration activities (of S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition) or IMG activities (of S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition), and configuration tables will be used in this blog post:

This blog post will be described in the context of public cloud.

TRM account determination logic at a glance

Assess the business requirement

Before starting configuration for account determination, please evaluate the business requirement for posting:

  1. What is the update type for which the posting should be generated? What is the economic essence behind it?
  2. What are the categories for the debit and credit entries of this posting? Is it a posting for position (book value) of the financial instrument, or customer or vendor subledger, or bank clearing account, or profit or loss account (with account assignment required like cost center), or others?
  3. What are the G/L account numbers should be used?
  4. If postings are to be made to vendors or customers, what are the reconciliation accounts or special G/L accounts (derived from reconciliation accounts and special G/L indicators)?

The order of configuration

  1. Define account symbols and specify the posting categories for the account symbols in configuration activity 102121. The available posting categories are:
    • 1 - Position Posting (Book Value) in Position Currency
    • 2 - Subledger Posting in Payment Currency
    • 3 - Bank Posting in Payment Currency
    • 4 - Profit-Related Posting in Position Currency
    • 5 - Profit-Related Posting in Payment Currency
    • 6 - Other G/L Posting in Position Currency
    • 7 - Other G/L Posting in Payment Currency
    • 10 - Currency Swap Between Position Currency / Payment Currency
    • 11- Tax Posting in Payment Currency
  2. Define posting specifications in node ‘Definition of Posting Specifications’ of configuration activity 103014, including document type, posting keys, account symbols, special G/L indicators (optional, only when posting to customer/vendor subledger) for debit and credit entries of the posting specification.
  3. Assign the posting specifications to the update types in node ‘Assignment of Update Types to Posting Specs’ of configuration activity 103014.
  4. Assign the G/L accounts to the account symbols, account assignment references (optional, but usually needed for most cases), valuation areas (optional), currencies (optional) in node ‘Assignment of G/L Accounts to Account symbols’ of configuration activity 103014.

A simple illustration

MM1150- is the update type of interest capitalization from the investment transactions of money market. MM1150- is assigned with the posting specification 13700, which can be seen from the node ‘Assignment of Update Types to Posting Specs’ of configuration activity 103014.

In the node ‘Definition of Posting Specifications’ of configuration activity 103014, check the posting specification 13700:

  • Document type: SA
  • Debit entry: posting key 40, account symbol 1 (posting category: 1 - Position Posting (Book Value) in Position Currency)
  • Debit entry: posting key 50, account symbol 4.1.3 (4 - Profit-Related Posting in Position Currency)

The account symbols are created and their posting categories are specified in configuration activity 102121:

In the node ‘Assignment of G/L Accounts to Account symbols’ of configuration activity 103014:

  • Assign G/L account 18030000 (Long Term Investments, Unaffiliated(TRM)) to account symbol 1 and account assignment reference 201100000000.
  • Assign G/L account 70200000 (Interest Income, Unaffiliated(TRM)) to account symbol 4.1.1 and account assignment reference 201100000000.

Posting result: when running TBB1/TPM10 for the interest capitalization flow using update type MM1150- from an investment money market transaction with account assignment reference 201100000000, the posting journal entry would be debiting 18030000 and crediting 70200000.

Position posting (book value) in position currency

To post to the financial assets or liabilities reflected in the position accounts of the financial instruments, please use an account symbol with posting category 1 - Position Posting (Book Value) in Position Currency.

The position accounts of the financial instruments include (but are not limited to) the long/short term investment or debt arising from debt instruments (e.g., deposits, CDs, loans, bonds, ABS/MBS), equity investments (e.g., stock, shareholding), fund investments, derivative assets or liabilities from derivative financial instruments (e.g., forwards, options, swaps), receivables or payables arising from trade finance contracts like letter of credit, regardless of how the G/L accounts of positions are named in your chart of accounts.

Usually, if an account symbol with posting category 1 is involved in an update type where the position change category cannot be automatically determined, especially for the update type mapped to an operational cash flow from financial transactions or securities account management, the update type should be assigned with a proper position change category in the configuration activity 102097 - Set Effects of Update Types on Position Components, to ensure that the effects on position changes in TRM position management and position accounts postings are consistent.

Examples:

Bank clearing account or Payment request clearing account

This section elaborates the usage of posting category 3 - Bank Posting in Payment Currency. Let’s have a look at the following example:

In configuration activity 102121 - Define Account Symbols, the account symbol 3 “Bank clearing” is defined with posting category 3.

In the node ‘Assignment of G/L Accounts to Account symbols’ of configuration activity 103014, in the field “G/L account”, the account mask “+++++++080” is assigned to the account symbol 3.

The posting spec 11100 is assigned to update type MM1100- (principal increase of investment transaction of money market). Posting spec 11100 credits account symbol 3.

Create an investment transaction for interest rate instrument. In the tab Payment Details, ‘Without’ is selected for “Payment Request” option of direction “outflow”, the house bank is DEBK1 and account ID is DEAC1.

In tab Cash Flow, the field “Payment Request” is empty for the principal increase flow as of 22.12.2025 (flow type 1100, direction ‘outflow’, update type MM1100-).

Run TBB1/TPM10 as of 22.12.2025. Check posting log:

The posting of MM1100- credits G/L account 0011001080.

How is 0011001080 determined?

System first finds out the G/L account of house bank DEBK1 and account ID DEAC1 of company code 1010, it is 0011001000 (the bank main account).

System them applies account mask +++++++080 (the “G/L account” assigned to account symbol 3) to the bank main account 0011001000:

  • The first 7digits of the bank main account 0011001000—0011001—are retained, as each "+" in the mask "+++++++080" indicates a character to be preserved.
  • The last 3 digits of the bank main account 0011001000 are replaced with the fixed characters "080" from the mask "+++++++080".
  • Combining 0011001 and 080 results in the bank sub-account (bank clearing account) 0011001080, which is then used for posting.

Let’s create another investment transaction for interest rate instrument. In the tab Payment Details, ‘With’ is selected for “Payment Request” option of direction “outflow”, the house bank is DEBK1 and account ID is DEAC1, the payer/payee and its partner bank (which are required in payment request) are also specified in the sub-area “Payment”.

In tab Cash Flow, the field “payment request” is “X” for the principal increase flow as of 22.12.2025 (flow type 1100, direction ‘outflow’, update type MM1100-).

Run TBB1/TPM10 as of 22.12.2025. Check posting log:

Now, the posting of MM1100- credits G/L account 21900000 (Payment Request Clearing Account (TRM)).

How is 21900000 determined?

When the “payment request” is ‘X’, system abandons the use of the bank clearing account. Instead, system retrieves the account maintained in configuration activity 105589 - Define Clearing Accounts for Cross-Country/Region Bank Account Transfers.

In TBB1, you can also check the payment log, in which you can find the payment request number.

Afterwards, please use the app Automatic Payment Transactions for Payment Request (transaction F111) to process the payment request, create accounting document debiting 21900000 and crediting bank clearing account (determined by payment program instead of TRM), and create the payment medium if necessary. The detailed process is not elaborated herein.

Summary:

  • For a payment-related flow where the relevant account symbol uses posting category 3, whether a bank clearing account or a payment request clearing account is called depends on whether its payment details use with or without payment request.
    • Without payment request: bank clearing account is determined by applying the account mask (e.g., “+++++++080” which is specified in configuration activity 103014’s "Assignment of G/L Accounts to Account Symbols" node) to the bank main account.
    • With payment request: payment request clearing account is called. Payment request clearing account is specified in the configuration activity 105589.
  • Bank clearing account (without payment request) is typically applicable to bank-initiated payments (e.g., most incoming payments), and its open items should subsequently be reconciled with bank statement items.
  • Payment requests are typically applicable to corporate-initiated payment scenarios, where the company should “inform” the bank to process the payment (e.g., via a payment medium sent to the bank).

Paying/Nonpaying valuation areas and Postings to customers or vendors

You may already aware that different posting specifications can be assigned to the same update type in the node ‘Assignment of Update Types to Posting Specs’ of configuration activity 103014, differentiated by the second column “Payment Transaction” (hereinafter referred to as “P”) and third column “Posted in Pay. VA”. For example:

  • 11100 is assigned to MM1100- with “P” unselected and “Not Specified” specified for “Posted in Pay. VA”.
  • 71100 is assigned to MM1100- with “P” selected and “Paying Valuation Areas” specified for “Posted in Pay. VA”.
  • 81100 is assigned to MM1100- with “P” selected and “Nonpaying Valuation Areas” specified for “Posted in Pay. VA”.

If “P” is selected, it means the intention is to generate posting to customer or vendor subledger (FI-AR / FI-AP). In this example, the purposes of 71100 and 81100 are to post to vendor in credit side.

The posting spec 11100 assigned to MM1100- with “P” unselected has been explained in above section “Bank clearing account or Payment request clearing account”, in which the credit entry is posted to bank clearing account or payment request clearing account, instead of vendor or customer.

We will elaborate details of posting specs 71100 and 81100 in current section:

  • 71100 is used for the postings in paying valuation area.
    • Credit entry’s account symbol is V.0 in this example, this account symbol must use posting category 2 - Subledger Posting in Payment Currency.
    • Credit entry’s posting key must be relevant to account type D (customer) or K (vendor). In this example, the posting key 34 is used, 34 is a posting key for account type K.
  • 81100 is used for the postings in nonpaying valuation areas.
    • Credit entry’s account symbol is V.0 in this example, this account symbol must use posting category 2 - Subledger Posting in Payment Currency.
    • Credit entry’s posting key must be relevant to account type S (G/L accounts), instead of account type D or K. In this example, the posting key 50 is used.

Let’s use the following example to illustrate the outcome of this configuration of 71100 and 81100.

Create an investment transaction for interest rate instrument. In the tab Payment Details, ‘to customer’ is selected for “Posting” option of direction “outflow”, which means for outflows, the postings should post to customer or vendor. Although it is called “to customer”, it can also post to vendor (actually it is controlled by posting key). In this example, because posting key 34 is used, and posting key 34 is relevant to account type K, so it posts to vendor instead of customer.

In tab Cash Flow, the field “Payment Transaction” is “X” (because ‘to customer’ is selected in Payment Details) for the principal increase flow as of 22.12.2025 (flow type 1100, direction ‘outflow’, update type MM1100-), indicating that it should post to customer or vendor. And the business partner entered in the field Payer/Payee (10537001 in this example) in sub-area “Payment” should be the customer or vendor (vendor in this example).

Run TBB1/TPM10 as of 22.12.2025 for all valuation areas (paying and nonpaying valuation areas). Check posting log:

1100- cash flow is “Payment Transaction” = “X” and DE0 is the paying valuation area, therefore, for the posting in DE0, MM1100- uses the posting spec 71100 which is assigned to MM1100- with “P” selected and “Paying Valuation Areas” specified for “Posted in Pay. VA” in the configuration.

Posting spec 71100 uses the posting key 34 which is for vendor (account type K), so system knows that it should post to the vendor 10537001 (the business partner entered in the field Payer/Payee of payment details in the transaction). In above screen-shot of posting log, the G/L account of posting key 34 is empty (it is not a bug!), this is because the TRM accounting interface passes on the vendor account 10537001 to FI directly, and FI determines the reconciliation account from the vendor master data of 10537001. Checking the line item of the journal entry, you will see it credits the vendor 10537001, and its reconciliation account 21100000 is also there in the line item. To ensure successful posting, the business partner 10537001 must be extended to the BP role FLVN00 (FI supplier) and the reconciliation account of vendor 10537001 must be maintained in advance.

1100- cash flow is “Payment Transaction” = “X” and 002 and 003 are the nonpaying valuation area, therefore, for postings in 002 and 003, MM1100- uses the posting spec 81100 which is assigned to MM1100- with “P” selected and “Nonpaying Valuation Areas” specified for “Posted in Pay. VA” in the configuration.

81100 uses the posting key 50 which is for account type S, and from the screen-shot of TRM posting log, you already see the reconciliation account 21100000 has been determined in TRM.

How does TRM determine reconciliation account 21100000 for nonpaying valuation areas:

  • 81100 uses the account symbol V.0 with posting category 2, so TRM knows it should post to vendor or customer.
  • TRM checks the corresponding posting spec 71100 used in the paying valuation area, 71100 uses posting key 34 for account symbol V.0, posting key 34 indicates that the posting is done to vendor.
  • Then TRM determines that the 81100 should also post to vendor’s reconciliation account.
  • TRM finds out the reconciliation account 21100000 from the vendor master data of 10537001 in corresponding company code.
  • 81100 directly posts to 21100000 using posting key 50, that means, 211000000 is provided in the TRM accounting interface to FI, and FI uses it for posting directly.

Therefore, from an accounting perspective, the credit postings in all valuation areas are recorded in reconciliation account 21100000 of vendor 10537001, even though the paying and nonpaying valuation areas differ in their realization methods.

A common FAQ is why different posting keys must be used for customer and vendor postings in paying versus nonpaying valuation areas for the same update type. In other modules (e.g., FI-AR, FI-AP), customer and vendor postings can be posted simultaneously in all ledgers (both leading and non-leading) without the need to specify a ledger group—meaning posting keys for account types D and K are valid for journals across all ledgers. By contrast, TRM always executes valuation area-dependent postings, which means postings from a paying valuation area are posted exclusively to the ledger group associated with the leading ledger, while those from a nonpaying valuation area are posted exclusively to the ledger group associated with the corresponding non-leading ledger. For customer and vendor postings in the leading ledger, posting keys for account types D and K are to be used (enabling open item management and subsequent clearing); however, for postings exclusive to non-leading ledgers, such posting keys are not permitted due to FI module design. This is why it is necessary to use posting keys 40 and 50 (or other account type S posting keys) for customer and vendor postings originating from nonpaying valuation areas.

Summary and Additional notes:

  • When posting category 2 is used, whether the posting is made to vendor or customer is decided by the account type of the posting key specified in the posting spec assigned to the update type with “P” selected and “Paying Valuation Areas” specified for “Posted in Pay. VA”.
    • If the posting key is for account type D (typically posting keys 01~19), it is posting to customer.
    • If the posting key is for account type K (typically posting keys 21~39), it is posting to vendor.
    • Paying valuation area: TRM directly passes on the posting key and business partner (payer/payee) to FI, and FI will determine it is posting to customer or vendor based on the account type of posting key.
    • Nonpaying valuation area: TRM determines it is customer or vendor based on the posting key of the corresponding posting spec used in paying valuation area, retrieves the reconciliation account of customer or vendor, and passes on the reconciliation account to FI for posting directly.
  • An account symbol with posting category 2 should be used exclusively with posting keys for either vendors or customers (not both) across all posting specifications. Improper configuration will trigger error message TPM_TRAC1 040 ("Cannot determine account type for account symbol V.0") in TBB1/TPM10.
    • Proper configuration examples:
      • In all posting specs, account symbol V.0 is only associated with posting keys for account type K (typically 21~39).
      • In all posting specs, account symbol V.0 is only associated with posting keys for account type D (typically 01~19).
    • Improper configuration example:
      • In some posting specs, account symbol V.0 is associated with posting keys for account type K (typically 21~39); whereas there are some other posting specs in which account symbol V.0 is associated with posting keys for account type D (typically 01~19).
  • The document type used for paying valuation area related posting spec should allow postings to account type D, if any account symbol in the posting spec uses posting category 2 and the posting key is for account type D (typically 01~19).
  • The document type used for paying valuation area related posting spec should allow postings to account type K, if any account symbol in the posting spec uses posting category 2 and the posting key is for account type K (typically 21~39).
  • Postings to special G/L accounts are also possible. To achieve it, please configure posting specifications like below:
    • Posting spec of paying valuation area:
      • If the need is to post to customer:
        • Use posting key 09 (debit) or 19 (credit)
        • Specify a proper and available Special G/L indicator for customer (account type D)
      • Or, if the need is to post to vendor:
        • Use posting key 29 (debit) or 39 (credit)
        • Specify a proper and available Special G/L indicator for vendor (account type K)
    • Posting spec of nonpaying valuation areas:
      • Use posting key 40 (debit) or 50 (credit) for customer or vendor
      • Specify the same Special G/L Indicator as that used in the corresponding posting spec for the paying valuation area.
    • The mapping of special G/L accounts to reconciliation accounts should already be configured in FI for the special G/L indicators of account type D or K.
    • Account determination logic:
      • Paying valuation area: similar to reconciliation account posting logic. TRM passes on the vendor/customer account (payer/payee) and special G/L indicator to FI via accounting interface, FI will use the vendor/customer account for posting directly, and FI will determine it’s vendor or customer from the account type of posting key and found out the special G/L account.
      • Nonpaying valuation areas: also similar to reconciliation account determination. TRM checks the posting keys of corresponding posting spec of paying valuation area, determines it is for vendor (posting key 29/39) or customer (posting key 09/19), finds out the reconciliation account, and determines the special G/L account of the reconciliation account and the special G/L indicator of account type D or K, passes on the special G/L account to FI posting directly.
  • The reconciliation account or special G/L account is used for vendor or customer related postings, and they are automatically determined (by FI for paying VA, or by TRM for nonpaying VAs), therefore, it is not necessary to assign and please do NOT assign any G/L accounts to account symbols with posting category 2 in node ‘Assignment of G/L Accounts to Account symbols’ of configuration activity 103014.
  • There is a sub-node “Assignment of Update Types to Posting Specs” under node “Valuation Areas” (table TRAC_DFTRULE2) in configuration activity 103014. TRAC_DFTRULE2 is used to assign different posting specs for the same update type in different valuation areas or company codes. Examples of application scenarios:
    • Different nonpaying valuation areas should use different posting specs for the same update type.
    • Different company codes should use different posting specs for the same update type in the same valuation area.
  • When considered alongside tables TRAC_DFTRULE1 (1st-level node: "Assignment of Update Types to Posting Specifications" in configuration activity 103014) and TRAC_DFTRULE2, the logic for determining the posting specification of an update type in a valuation area is as follows:
  • If "To Customer" is selected in the Payment Details (where the field "Payment Transaction" is set to "X" for cash flow) in a transaction, a posting spec must be assigned to the corresponding update type—with "P" (Payment Transaction) selected—in TRAC_DFTRULE1 or TRAC_DFTRULE2 in configuration activity 103014. If this is not the case, the system cannot determine the posting spec and will issue an error message when executing TBB1/TPM10.

Profit-related postings

The posting category 4 - Profit-Related Posting in Position Currency or 5 - Profit-Related Posting in Payment Currency should be used for the account symbols assigned with the profit or loss G/L accounts which are set up as primary cost elements (cost element category 1 - Primary costs).

The primary cost element needs account assignments (e.g., cost center) during posting. Only with posting category 4 or 5, the account assignments in treasury position indicator will be passed on to accounting document line items.

A frequently seen issue: the cost center appears in the position indicator of a treasury transaction (via any workable means mentioned in blog post Account Assignment in TRM Financial Transactions - Cost Center). However, this cost center is not used for postings done by TBB1 or TPM10, and error message like “account assignment can’t be determined for cost element” is raised. The cause could be that the relevant account symbols (assigned with cost element in node “Assignment of G/L Accounts to Account symbols”) doesn’t use posting category 4 or 5.

Currency swap between position currency and payment currency

The usage of posting category 10 - Currency Swap Between Position Currency / Payment Currency is special. In this example, the account symbol 9.1.4 uses posting category 10.

Account symbol 9.1.4 is not used in any posting specs.

A technical clearing account 22549000 is assigned to account symbol 9.1.4.

In the names of posting categories, you always see “…in payment currency” or “…in position currency”, these indicate which currency is the transaction currency in accounting documents—payment currency or position currency.

When a posting spec involves two account symbols posted in different currencies—one is in payment currency and the other is in position currency, then the account 22549000 will be automatically involved.

For example, the posting spec 11100 is assigned to update type MM1902- (which is capitalized charges). 11100 debits with account symbol 1 (posting in position currency) and credits with account symbol 3 (posting in payment currency).

Now assume the position currency of the transaction if USD (the principal and interest are paid in USD), however, the charge MM1902- is paid in EUR. Check the posting log for MM1902-:

MM1902- credits bank clearing account in the transaction currency EUR (=payment currency of this flow), but its debit side recognizes position which is posted in transaction currency USD (=position currency of this transaction). In this case, two accounting documents are created for MM1902-:

  • One uses transaction currency USD, debits position account and credits technical clearing account 22549000;
  • The other uses the transaction currency EUR, debits technical clearing account 22549000 and credits bank clearing account.

The technical clearing account 22549000 is involved in two documents, and it has identical amounts in valuation currency within two accounting documents.

This kind of handling is necessary because only one single transaction currency is allowed in one accounting document (design of FI).

entry.title: Re: ME21N Retention fields – which CDS view contains them?
entry.content:
Hi,

In S/4HANA Public Cloud, the Retention field you see in Create Purchase Order – Advanced is UI-only.

  • The field is not currently exposed

  • It is not part of the Purchase Order API

  • It is not extensible via: Custom fields (key-user extensibility), CDS view extensions or Badi.

Retention cannot be passed via the Purchase Order API in S/4HANA Public Cloud currently.

Since this is a system limitation, please log a customer influence request. The development team monitors these requests and if it is within the scope of implementation, this will be put on SAP Road Map Explorer.

  1. Get started by opening SAP Customer Influence SAP Continuous Influence sessions for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition 
  2. Register and accept the Terms of Use
  3. Choose a session of your interest
  4. Create and submit your improvement request
  5. Take a look at existing improvement requests and start voting and commenting

Thanks and regards,

Krithika

entry.title: Re: Moniter Material Coverage_Suppier
entry.content:
Dear @ISoma,

In Monitor Material Coverage app the Supplier Name / Supplier Number columns are populated only when the system can determine or already has a source of supply for the material/plant

A supplier is shown when at least one of the following is true:

1. A procurement element already exists with a supplier

  • For example: a purchase order, scheduling agreement schedule line or a purchase requisition that already has a source assigned vendor/outline agreement

2. MRP source determination can select a valid source of supply
During the planning run, the system searches for a valid source in this order:

  • Quota arrangement including source list entries with MRP indicator
  • Source list with MRP indicator
  • Scheduling agreement
  • Purchasing contract
  • Purchasing info record with automatic sourcing indicator

If none of these yields a valid source validity dates, not blocked, applicable org/plant, etc.), the supplier fields remain blank

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3531581

If multiple Purchasing Info Records exist, will they all be displayed?

No, the app will not list all possible suppliers/info records for a row. It shows the one source that MRP selected/assigned for that material/plant

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Contingent Worker/External to Employee Conversions through Onboarding
entry.content: We have a terrible process to handle contingent worker to employee conversions.  We track our contingent workers in EC through Work Orders.  The contingent applies to a job through the external career site (because they are not employees) and if offered the job, the recruiter initiates onboarding.  Typically, they come up in rehire validation/employment selection profile.  The onboarding admin does not accept the match and selects to proceed as new hire.  Now there are two records for this person.  The onboardee completes their onboarding tasks.  The onboarding admin downloads all of the documents, takes a print screen of the new hire validation/personal information data, cancels the onboarding and rehires them in using the Add New Employee.  When the rehire validation comes up, the admin selects rehire with new employment and then the records are combined.  The issue is the onboarding record leaves a cancelled record that needs to be purged.  If the onboarding admin forgets to remove the national ID, they cannot use the add new employee functionality and the purge becomes urgent.  With 1H 2025, SAP introduced the Legal Entity transfer.  We thought this would work for us, but because the contingent  worker applies on the external site to go through initiate onboarding so they can complete their compliance tasks.  They do not receive the Legal Entity Transfer Welcome Mail and cannot toggle between profiles because they did not apply internally.  Are any other customers having this issue.  Is the way you solved for it to allow CWs to apply through internal career site and if so, how do you assign the I-9 and other compliance tasks?  Any assistance is appreciated.

This is the SAP Developer News for January 22nd, 2026.

00;01;28;22 - 00;01;58;22

Hola developers! Are you using the event mesh capability and you also use cloud them for monitoring? Well, here's some news for you. It is now possible to monitor the event mesh capability directly in SAP cloud ALM, meaning that you can now not just monitor your cloud integration tenant, but also your event mesh capability program for the broker. entry.title: Re: Understanding GOS Attachments in SAP: Tables, Storage, and Reporting Best Practices

entry.title: My Journey Building a Mobile‑Friendly Fiori App Using AI and Vibe Coding
entry.content:
and saga continues...

Figure 1. Screenshots from mobile phone that show main app functionality

 

UPDATE from my previous posts:

https://blogs.sap.com/2016/08/16/build-your-own-sap-fiori-app-in-the-cloud-2016-edition/

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-members/kiko3-sap-fiori-user-administration/

Please read my previous blog so you can familiarize yourself and be up to speed with the current blog post.


My idea was to enable basic user‑administration tasks — locking and unlocking users, setting a new initial password, and adjusting a user’s validity date — to be performed directly from a mobile phone instead of requiring a laptop. This isn’t meant for everyday office use, but it’s extremely helpful in global companies with on‑call teams supporting users in multiple time zones.

A typical scenario for this app is when you’re away from your desk — for example, sitting in a park or waiting at an airport — and you suddenly need to perform one of these tasks. Instead of opening your laptop and spending 15–30 minutes connecting and navigating through the system, you can complete everything on your mobile device in under five minutes.

Your phone can first connect to the corporate network through a VPN app, and the 2FA code arrives on the same device. From there, you simply open the corporate URL linked to the Fiori app. After setting the new initial password and unlocking the user, you can immediately send an email notification containing the credentials you just generated.

This approach makes user‑administration tasks faster, more convenient, and perfectly suited for real‑world on‑call situations.

Let’s look at how a typical real‑world scenario usually unfolds — and whether there’s room to improve the process. In most cases, it consists of just 2–3 simple steps.

Step 1

Ivana (SAP user): I’m locked out of the SAP system. Could you please unlock my user?
You: Your user has been unlocked.

…a few minutes later…

Step 2

Ivana (SAP user): Could you please reset my password and unlock my user again? It seems I forgot it.
You: Your user is unlocked and the new initial password is: XXXXXX.

…a few minutes later…

Step 3

Ivana (SAP user): My SAP user is no longer valid…
You: Please try now — I’ve extended your validity date for two weeks.

One thing that first came to my mind is when you unlocking user, adding additional check if validity date is in the past, also if you are setting new initial password for user that is already locked unlock it and also check if validity date is in the past. If you find that validity date is in the past show warning message about validity date, as showed in Figure 2.

 Figure 2. Screenshots shows setting new initial password, automatically unlocking and warning message for validity date in past 

When I started building this app, I had no idea there was a name for what I was doing. I was simply copying pieces of code from my custom Fiori app, pasting them into an AI chat window, and asking it to “add this” or “fix that.” It felt a bit like having a super‑fast coding partner who never sleeps and never complains.

Every time I uploaded a new version, I hoped it would work — and sometimes it did. Out of 110 versions I tried, around 30 were perfectly fine. The rest were a mix of broken logic, misunderstandings, or classic AI hallucinations. In other words, about 27% of the time, things worked exactly the way I imagined.

But here’s the interesting part: even with all the trial and error, I managed to implement every single idea that came to mind. I would think of a feature, describe it to the AI, and a few minutes later I had a working version (or at least something close enough to refine). Only later did I discover that this whole approach actually has a name — vibe coding — and that many developers are already using it to speed up their workflow.

Looking back, the process wasn’t perfect, but it was surprisingly effective. And honestly, it was fun — like building something together with an unpredictable but incredibly creative teammate.

I have always using new increment in version when uploading  (Name of SAPUI5 App) custom Fiori to avoid issue with cache.

SE38 -> /UI5/UI5_REPOSITORY_LOAD

 Figure 3. captures the different versions I uploaded as I worked through this entire process

Version History
Added SAP theme selection option
Added application logo
Implemented Lock/Unlock functionality with automatic refresh after each operation
Added unlock warning when the user’s validity date is in the past
Improved password reset flow: when setting a new initial password, the app automatically unlocks the user (if locked) and checks the validity date
Enhanced validity date handling: when updating validity, the app now suggests a default date 10 days from today and refreshes after saving
Added quick‑filter buttons:
 - Show Locked (users with uflag > 0)
 - Show Invalid (users with a validity date in the past)
Added SID/Client input field before the Search bar
Improved Search behavior: entering two or more characters automatically displays matching users
Added in ABAP code option to search by last name/surname

For demo and full functionality of this Fiori app, please check video on Youtube.

Conclusion

What began as an experiment turned into a practical tool that saves time, reduces friction, and makes on‑call support far more manageable. With AI‑assisted development becoming more accessible, this is just the beginning. I’m excited to see how these new workflows will continue to reshape the way we build and interact with enterprise applications.

NOTE: All screenshots and the video were taken on an iPhone 17, using the Demo21 S/4HANA 2022 – 01 (02/2023) FPS environment.

Feel free to share your thoughts on this article or suggest any features you’d like to see added to the app. 😃

entry.title: Why Bringing SAP to Agentic SDK via Regular MCP Server Is Not Good Enough
entry.content:
Advocating Technology

Let me name things properly – we have lots of noise around AI. Companies are trying to jump into the technology because they think that Business AI is simple, that it is just a kind of ChatGPT that gets access to business data. Sounds simple, doesn’t it?

I strongly disagree! Bringing SAP data to an Agentic SDK, like Claude or SAP Joule, does not mean delivering Business AI. It is far away from even an understanding of business needs. I know, you start hating me 😊. And the only reason for the internal opinion in your head is that you are most probably one of the MCP bridge providers that think that wrapping APIs (I will not write “discover OData via MCP Server,” because the whole SAP community will hate me :D), or wrapping SAP tables/views, or wrapping SAP function modules is the way to bring SAP data to Business AI. 

How many posts do we see now on LinkedIn where people are happy like kids seeing data from an agentic SDK, e.g. Claude Desktop, returned by OData that is called via an MCP Server and shown as a table. Wow-wow! A list of Purchase Orders! As a table! Based on my utterance! C’mon people, we are not in 2017 when we, together with the SAP Conversational AI team, were happy to see such kinds of cases. Yes, 9 years ago it was innovation, not now. Why not post on LinkedIn that the same OData service draws an even nicer table in a standard SAP Fiori app showing a list of Purchase Orders with… OMG… DRILL DOWN!!! 😊

Why am I writing this? Just to emphasize that Business AI is an excellent technology that is now far beyond strange posts where people see SAP data in another UI than GUI or Fiori. Real Business AI returns investment, works autonomously, and understands data. For example, an AI agent that gets emails from customers with purchase orders from their systems confirming the deals we’ve made with them. That AI agent posts those emails to SAP, creating Sales Orders, for sure not using OData. Why not? Because there are two EntitySet calls you need to do to create a Sales Order via OData, and you need to be able to simulate a batch call; otherwise, you will get lots of Sales Order headers in your SAP productive system when the OData call for Sales Order Items has failed.

 Pic.1 Example from LinkedIn Article – Creating Sales Order via OData without Batch Mode

However, even creating a Sales Order from my example is not the biggest challenge for that AI agent.

The Biggest Challenge

SAP data and the “bridges” we build to connect AI agents with SAP via “regular” MCP servers, this is the biggest challenge we create for AI agents. Sometimes it seems that after allocating a really good business case, we are doing everything possible to push the AI agent to fail 😊.

SAP data preparation is the boring, but extremely essential, step here. We should think about what we feed to the AI agent when asking it to read an email and post a Sales Order in the SAP system. We need to give the AI agent a chance to query master data that is so essential for that AI automation scenario and allocate master data in a robust and reliable way, independent of how the customer names our services and products in their systems.

SAP Master Data Vectorization

Let’s see a simple example we have created using the ChatGPT UI showing how different AI agents will act if you prepare and only then bridge SAP data properly. We will use two MCP servers for this:

  • Regular MCP Server for SAP Data (any MCP server, we do not like to point fingers at someone’s solution; we’d like to advocate AI automation only)

  • Skybuffer AI MCP Server for SAP Data (here we have a data preparation layer where we vectorize SAP master data first)

 Pic.2 SAP Master Data Vectorization as a Data Preparation Step

See the Difference

Now let’s simulate a request from an AI agent that is working autonomously and has responsibility to create Sales Orders in an SAP production system with the maximum level of automation.

Here is a simple example of a regular MCP Server failure, just because the customer captured data in their system a bit differently from our SAP productive system:

Pic.3 Regular MCP Server for SAP Data – Failing on the Simple Case of Small Wording Differences

And now let’s see how easily and robustly an AI agent gets information from the same SAP system, but via an MCP Server that reads prepared SAP master data for AI automation:

 Pic.4 Skybuffer AI MCP Server – Easy and Robust Access to SAP Master Data

Now you see that 99% of all examples or success stories from LinkedIn about how fast we can create MCP servers to bridge SAP data and how reusable OData services are, are solutions that are far away from productive implementation (unless you are OK with getting a 50% automation rate 😊).

Conclusion

Indeed, MCP servers that consume OData, tables/views, etc. make sense for some steps in AI automation. However, we need to be very careful, and we should not mix hype with productive implementations. A good MCP server bridges prepared SAP data that an AI agent can consume to provide a maximal rate of automation that will reach 100% in a short time of productive usage. Saving on implementation ruins the impression of Business AI and reduces trust in it. Let’s not harm our overall revenue and investment return, and think twice whether the bridge we build for an AI agent suits the goal.

Imagine connecting the Skybuffer AI MCP Server to SAP Joule, making it able to understand user input by similarities. How powerful would your SAP Joule implementation be, and how smoothly would SAP Joule understand requests? Skybuffer AI runs on SAP BTP, providing a hidden but necessary layer for SAP Joule that can properly bridge your SAP on-premise data.

Closing Statement

Good luck with AI automation implementations, and do not hesitate to ask questions, collaborate, and bring technology to customers in a way they benefit from it, not just seeing the hype in it.

entry.title: How does Effort Deviation adjustment persist across periods when Forecast Month changes?
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

I am analyzing the CDS view I_EngmntProjFcstCube_2 in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and have a question about how ActualPlanDeviationEffort is calculated across multiple periods when the Forecast Month changes.

Background

According to KBA 3617498, when a Forecast Month is set, the system calculates Effort Deviation based on the difference between Planned Effort and Actual Effort, and an adjustment value is applied during this calculation (related to ETC/EAC logic).

My Question

I am trying to understand what happens to this adjustment value when the Forecast Month moves from one period to the next:

Scenario:

  • Month 1 (e.g., May 2024): Forecast Month is set → Deviation adjustment is applied → ActualPlanDeviationEffort = X

  • Month 2 (e.g., June 2024): Forecast Month moves forward → New deviation is calculated

Which of the following happens?

Option A: Reset and Recalculate

  • The adjustment applied in Month 1 is reversed/cancelled

  • A fresh adjustment is calculated for Month 2 based on current Planned vs. Actual

  • Each period's deviation is independent

Option B: Cumulative/Persistent

  • The adjustment from Month 1 remains/persists into Month 2

  • Additional adjustments in Month 2 are added on top of Month 1's adjustment

  • Deviations carry forward across periods

Option C: Distributed

  • The adjustment is redistributed evenly across all remaining periods up to the Forecast Month

  • As mentioned in the documentation, adjustments are distributed across demands for the same role

Why This Matters

In our data, for period 2024005:

  • PlndEffortQty = 35

  • ActlEffortQty = 2

  • Expected deviation: 2 - 35 = -33

  • Actual ActualPlanDeviationEffort: -28

The difference of 5 hours seems to be an adjustment, but I cannot understand whether this adjustment was applied once in period 2024005, or if it's affected by adjustments from previous periods.

Has anyone worked with this logic or can point me to documentation that explains the period-by-period behavior of these deviation adjustments?​

entry.title: S/4 HANA: In The Era of Intelligent ERP
entry.content:
ERP systems have evolved beyond solely managing and maintaining documents; they now serve as the digital core of the enterprise. SAP S/4HANA marks a new era of intelligent ERP, where real-time data, embedded analytics, and AI-driven automation come together to provide businesses with agility, resilience, and foresight.
 
Transitioning from SAP ECC to S/4HANA: 5 Key Changes to Business Operations
Transitioning from SAP ECC to S/4HANA isn’t simply a technical upgrade; it’s actually a business reset. The primary benefit organizations notice when adopting S/4HANA is the improved processing speed. Real-time processing eliminates batch jobs and enables leaders to base decisions on facts instead of assumptions. Finance closes in days instead of weeks, supply chains adapt faster, and sales teams have better visibility into operations. One thing that doesn’t change enough is your business processes. Moving to S/4 forces companies to question old ways of working that no longer add value. Done properly, it streamlines operations and enhances the user experience for every function. Transformation works when business and IT align and embrace the change together. If one side is left behind, S/4HANA will fail to realize its full potential and instead become a costly replacement. ERP Transformation is less about migrating to new technology and more about changing mindsets.
 
Intelligent ERP as a Decision Engine, Not a Transaction System.
Originally, ERP systems were designed to record past business activities. Intelligent ERP flips the script. Real-time visibility combined with embedded analytics within S/4HANA enables teams to act proactively by breaking data out of silos prior to crises. Inventory shortages? Demand changes? Risky operations? They’re all visible long before they become problems. But it gets better. The business achieves extraordinary success when ERP systems empower leadership teams to make more informed decisions beyond operational management. Fewer lengthy meetings. Less escalate-this! And executable plans that everyone buys into. An ERP designed exclusively for transaction management serves the same limited function as a phone restricted to text messaging capabilities. Intelligent ERP transforms data into a powerful tool that enables informed decision-making. That’s indispensable. That’s intelligent ERP.
 
Supply Chain Visibility in the Age of Real-Time ERP
Supply chains today operate in a world of constant disruption.  Real-time ERP changes how organizations respond. Instead of reacting to delays or shortages, teams gain visibility into risks as they emerge. This enables proactive planning, faster mitigation, and better collaboration across functions. S/4HANA integrates planning, execution, and analytics into a single digital core. The result is not just transparency, but confidence in decision-making. Resilient supply chains are built on visibility, agility, and trust in data. Real-time ERP provides all three. The future of supply chain leadership is insight-driven, not reactive.
 
Omnichannel Availability: The Backbone of Modern Retail
Despite the absence of ERP systems, customers experience the impact daily. Omnichannel availability is no longer just an advantage for retailers; it's now a requirement. Accurate inventory management across multiple channels ensures customer trust and maintains consistent revenue, whether it is done through online channels or through partners. The challenge isn't demand. It's synchronization. The absence of a unified ERP backbone leads to mismatches in inventory, which causes lost sales and operational inefficiencies. The implementation of S/4HANA enables organizations to monitor supply and demand in real-time across all channels, simplifying the process. A seamless inventory movement leads to improved customer experience without any additional complexity.
 
Why most S/4HANA Transformations Often Struggle with Adoption
A significant proportion of S/4HANA programs underestimate the readiness of individuals while prioritizing system readiness. New interfaces, reworked processes, and real-time reporting necessitate that users work differently. Resistance arises when change management is not a priority. Why? Training alone isn't enough. Understanding the reasons behind process changes and their impact on daily work is crucial for users. Effective changes involve effective communication, successful role-based enablement, and sponsorship of leaders from the leadership level on the first day. The ERP's value is not realized until the system is deployed, but only after users have adopted it.
 
The transition from SAP ECC to S/4HANA involves more than just technology; it requires real-time data, optimized processes, and better decision-making. Intelligent ERP helps finance, supply chain, and retail sectors by eliminating data silos and identifying risks early. S/4HANA supports modern needs like supply chain resilience and multi-channel inventory management. Effective business-IT alignment and user adoption are crucial for maximizing transformation benefits.

entry.title: A simplified approach to choosing between S/4HANA Public vs Private Cloud
entry.content:
One of the fundamental decisions that organisations are facing as they plan their transition to Cloud ERP, is the deployment option to chose. In SAP terms the question becomes: Would S/4HANA Private Cloud or S/4HANA Public Cloud be the better choice?

At high level, S/4HANA Private Cloud is a "tailored-to-fit" solution enabling flexibility and customization, while S/4HANA Public Cloud is a "ready-to-run" solution prioritizing standardization and deployment speed. In reality, the selection between the two is more complex with different parameters to consider. This article aims to ease the decision process through a simplified approach.

The right deployment option could, and most often should, be subject to a series of workshops and careful assessment of an organization's specific needs. Still, experience from customer engagements has enabled me to develop a simplified approach which helps provide initial steering.

Overall, where possible, S/4HANA Public Cloud should be the go-to deployment option. This is due to its unique qualities, including faster access to innovation, a simpler Cloud operating model and reduced TCO. On the flip side, Public Cloud also comes with limitations as compared to S/4HANA Private Cloud. These include a narrower implementation scope (worth noting that Public Cloud's scope is more than enough for most organizations), reduced system control (which again may not be a concern for most organizations) and the need to leave customer customisations behind (which could actually benefit an organization's move towards a Clean Core).

To simplify the decision, as a rule of thumb an organisation should opt for S/4HANA Public Cloud if the following three elements match their needs:

  • S/4HANA Public Cloud implementation scope. Public Cloud offers  broad functionality covering the needs of most organizations and is becoming constantly richer in scope. Still, some functionality such as industry-specific scenarios may be unique to Private Cloud. The way to confirm that Public Cloud is fit for purpose is by completing the SAP Digital Discovery Assessment.
  • New implementation as migration option. A migration option to Public Cloud can be completed only via a new implementation, while a migration to Private Cloud can also be completed via a system conversion or Selective Data transition for organizations on a legacy SAP ERP system. If you are new to SAP, then a new implementation is your only way forward and should not be  a consideration. If you are moving from a legacy SAP ERP system though, then it is key to validate that a new implementation is right for you. A new implementation requires that custom code and custom processes from your legacy SAP ERP system are left behind - which could actually be an opportunity for moving to a Clean Core and reinventing business processes using SAP's Best Practices. A new implementation also requires that previous transactional data aka closed items are left behind e.g. archived, otherwise maintained in the legacy ERP system (online as read-only or offline as a backup/image). Unless there is a specific need to bring closed items to the new Cloud ERP environment, leaving these behind helps run a lighter, easier to maintain and more cost-efficient system.
  • Public Cloud Operating model. Public Cloud is equivalent to SaaS, as opposed to Private Cloud which is similar to IaaS/PaaS. This means that Public Cloud is highly standardized, enabling rapid innovation at a lower TCO, offering a Clean Core and SAP‑controlled operations and allowing the customer to focus on what matters to them most. It comes with Application Management Services included, therefore, among others, SAP is taking care of  application management including release updates and Middleware. Still, in Public Cloud, extensibility options are limited (classic ABAP extensibility not possible), the customer has no control over release upgrades (these are mandatory without the option to postpone and with a time-restricted regression testing window), and has no control over infrastructure choices either (Hyperscaler selection). Unless the organization has a particular need for any of these or for an operating model of shared responsibility with SAP, then Public Cloud should be the way forward.

While the above three elements focus mostly on the technical aspects of the deployment option decision, it comes without saying that the company's culture is also a major decisive factor. The appetite to reimagine processes and outsource a large part of IT operations to the software vendor while re-focusing on innovation activities, are important elements for a Public Cloud deployment.

To summarise, if you are an organisation planning a transition to SAP’s Cloud ERP and considering your deployment option, your actionable next steps are as follows: complete the SAP Digital Discovery Assessment to confirm whether the scope of S/4HANA Public Cloud matches your functionality needs, evaluate whether a new implementation is fit for purpose, and assess whether the Public Cloud operating model suits you. If the answer to all three questions is yes, and you have or manage to establish the right company culture, then you should lead with S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Disclaimer: The approach suggested in this article reflects my views based on experience from working with different organizations, rather than SAP's official views. It aims to provide simplified guidelines and initial steering, but does not replace the need for more thorough assessment.

entry.title: Configure Role Owner Stage Auto Approval in SAP IAG
entry.content:
Introduction

This blog explains how to configure Role Owner Stage Auto Approval in IAG. focusing on setting up the required data objects, business rules, and workflow configuration to automate approvals.

Step 1: Create Data Object

Create a data object called RoleOwnerAttributes. This object holds the input values used to determine whether the Role Owner stage should be automatically approved.

Add the following attributes to the data object:

  • roleName (String)
  • roleCriticality (String)
  • roleApprover (String)
  • roleBusinessProcess (String)
  • roleSubprocess (String)
  • roleRiskCount (Number)








 

 

 

Step 2: Create another Data Object 

Create another data object called AutoApproveRoleOwnerStage. This object stores the output of the rule.

Add the following attributes to the data object:

  • roleName (String)
  • roleOwnerAutoStage (Boolean)

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Step 3: Create Local Rule

Create a local rule called RoleOwnerStageAutoRule

decision table settings:

  • Use the fields from RoleOwnerAttributes (Step 1) as the conditions.
  • Use AutoApproveRoleOwnerStage (Step 2) as the result.

Result Attributes:

  • Role Owner Auto Stage → Access: Editable
  • Role Name → Access: Hidden
  • Set the hardcoded value as the roleName from RoleOwnerAttributes.


 

 

 

 

 

 

 


In this scenario, the condition is defined based on the Role Name.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Step 4: Create Rule Set

 

Create a rule set called RoleOwnerRuleSet  and add the local rule RoleOwnerStageAutoRule (from Step 3) to it.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 
Step 5: Create Rule Service

Create a rule service called AutoApproveRoleOwnerStage.

  • Import → RoleOwnerAttributes (from Step 1)

  • Result → AutoApproveRoleOwnerStage (from Step 2)

 

 

 

 

 
 
 
 
Step 6: Assign Rule Service

Assign the rule service AutoApproveRoleOwnerStage (from Step 5) to the rule set RoleOwnerRuleSet (from Step 4).

 

 

 

 

 
 
 
Step 7: Activate and Deploy

Activate all the created objects and deploy the business rule service. If any changes are made, the service must be deployed again.

Existing Workflow Setup

In the current existing workflow, the access request is configured to follow the Role Owner approval path as the stage 1 during the approval process.

 

 

 

 

 
 
 
Testing Scenario

The following test scenario was performed to validate the configuration:

  • An access request was raised for the role PR_approver_0_1M.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

  • The audit log shows that the request was automatically approved by the system.

  • The Access request status shows that it moved to the Risk Owner stage, confirming that the Role Owner stage was automatically approved successfully.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 
Conclusion

Role Owner stage auto approval reduces manual effort and speeds up the approval process for eligible access requests. Using rule-based conditions, organizations can automatically approve condition based requests while keeping manual approvals for critical cases.
